Unlike the politicians and the police, the Judiciary in India remains uncorrupted. With the meager salary Justices receive, it takes courage and character to do the work of justice. The Supreme Court of India still remains the only bastion of hope for the millions who struggle to make a living in India. A destitute citizen can file a writ petition even through a simple letter written on a post card.
In a landmark judgement dated December 16, 1983 Justice P.N. Bhagawati treated a letter from an NGO dedicated to the cause of release of bonded laborers in India, as a writ petition seeking the release of 58 loborers. Justice Bhagawati stated in his judgement,
"The letter dated 25th February 1982 addressed by the petitioner was treated as a writ petition and by an order dated 26th February 1982 this Court issued notice on the writ petition and appointed two advocates namely, M/s. Ashok Srivastava and Ashok Panda as
commissioners to visit the stone quarries." (Bandhua Mukti Morcha vs Union of India (UOI) and Ors

@Ananya, I'm well aware of Conrad, Nabokov and the Indian writers and poets. I'm well aware too of South Asian history, especially the British period 1757-1947.

What I'm talking about is not literary or academic English, which second language writers, such as Conrad, Nabokov and others can manage just fine. I'm talking about everyday speech and everyday language, the kind that we learn as children, the mother tongue. Non-native speakers cannot manage that spontaneously.

I've heard Nabokov (long ago), Arundhati Roy, Salman Rushdie and some other ESL writers speak. They do just fine when they are talking about literature or politics or about their books, but ask them, "How do I tie my shoes?" or "How do I turn cartwheels?" or "How do I climb a tree?" and they'll get tongue tied. I've seen this over and over again. The English language for them is more of an intellectual activity than it is for native speakers (Conrad famously dreamed in Polish). Native speakers (whether of American English, British English, Indo-Aryan or Dravidian languages) who have no previous experience with such questions---such as lifelong bachelors---will still be quickly able to invent the casual words.

Everyday speech has the indelible stamp of culture. That is what people typically consider when they say, "So and so is American (or Indian)," though I do understand that there is a more nuanced spectrum there of such identities.

@Paul Can you clarify? Hype about what? The picture shows contrast and change.

The sari---for thousands of years the draped attire of Indian women---is fast disappearing, especially among the young urban set. The swiftness of the change is very similar to what happened in the west during and immediately after the first world war when ankle length skirts disappeared and hemlines rose to just below the knee, or in southeast Asia in the 70s when the sarong made a similar quick exit.

In India, the sari has been replaced by jeans, salwars (loose harem pants), or churidars (tight pants increasingly made of spandex and bunched up above the ankle), like the kind the woman is wearing. The scooter has become the vehicle of choice of females between 13 and 25. I commonly see two or three teenage girls on a scooter on their carefree way to somewhere.

Most females don't wear helmets, though it is mandatory for the men. The government tried to mandate the same for women, but they protested that it flattened the coiffure. The woman isn't veiled, she's dressed that way to keep the dust and pollution out (for reasons of both health and vanity), Some women also wear what look like arm-length formal gloves to keep the dust and sun out (also for reasons of health and vanity.)

@ Mitra - You are looking at things from the other extreme compared to Kumar here.

Condemning the entire India police force as "corrupt" is very cynical and obviously untrue. Plus, police can't barge into people's homes without a warrant to do so - everybody knows this and a few solitary policemen barging into people's homes extorting money would only get them lynched by a mob - not rich in India's cities.

Just as the police isn't breaking into people's homes looking for "sodomites" and people having "unnatural sex" ( a law even the Supreme Court justices mocked for its absurdity!) similarly this "porn" law is utterly absurd. Just because some Victorian era puritanical elements like the preach their brand of hypocrisy as "holier-than-thou" platitudes doesn't mean such ridiculous laws could ever be enforced.

As to "other countries" and their superior record of women's rights - which countries are you referring to specifically ? Comparing India to Sweden or Switzerland is absurd to say the least. In South Asia, the Indian constitution offers the most progressive and egalitarian law possible. It is easy to be swept up in the rhetoric of outrage and dubious catchphrases of "rape capital" etc but the facts are that New Delhi sees less rapes than many Western cities per capita.
There is no law being passed just a petition posed to the Supreme Court by a concerned citizen. The Supreme Court cannot make laws - only recommend or interpret the law.

Controllable ? You seem to be under the impression that New Delhi police just watch as mute spectators while rapes take place all around them! That is absurd.

The police to citizen ratio in India is one of the lowest in the world, far lower than what the UN recommends. There is literally 1 police man for every 1000 citizens - often even less in remote areas and the police forces are so understaffed and over burdened that a typical police officer spends 16 hours a day on the job 6 days a week or more. They are responsible for everything from terrorism to traffic with a budget hardly sufficient to pay all their ranks and keep the lights on. Plus these police officers have to deal with local politicians and ministers who can influence who gets a promotion, who gets transferred and more. Juggling all these political pressures, with inadequate resources and too few men while the public demands better policing that most Western cities is not always possible.

You mean open up "gentlemen clubs" and legalize pornography and prostitution to be as "enlightened" as the West when it comes to "women's rights" ?

The people you term as "prudes" and "repressed" can also turn around and label your society "vulgar" and "deviant" and many in Asia, Africa and the Middle East do. Just because sex is not blatant, open and in your face doesn't imply that people are "repressed" .

Rape has nothing to do with "sex" - this is well understood. Rape is about "power". And in this case in India, the feeling of powerlessness in the more traditional patriarchal elements of society that find women's new social and economic freedom and assertiveness threatening. That's why they see women who go clubbing/drinking/consorting with men late into the night etc are "loose" and deserving "punishment".

Even I know that Shamshad Begum was not a "Bollywood" singer. The world Bollywood didn't exist before the 1980s and she had stopped singing by then.

She was a great Urdu ghazal singer and one of the first playback singers of Hindi cinema.

Also, "Begum" is a Muslim female honorific. No one is called "Mrs Begum." That would be like calling "Dame Margaret Thatcher," "Mrs Dame." There's a limit to which you can stretch the house style of a newspaper before it slips into absurdity.

All in all, a very poorly written obituary. Does disservice to a great singer.

All these single-sex educational institutions are generally Christian Missionary schools that prescribe a strict Victorian ethic system of puritanism - not Hindu.
Some "cultures" in the North and to the West are more conservative and keep girls cloistered till they are married off but even that is highly rare and impractical in today's generation of Indian youngsters. It is also impractical in the Indian workspace to practice this kind of segregation and even deeply religious Muslims women eschew the hijab in the workspace.

As to witch burning, that hasn't taken place in India since Gandhi was a child. A few tribal communities still believe in "witches" and "demons" but the practice of burning somebody alive is rare because only nobie women were burnt alive as part of a ritual display of devotion.

Demolishing temples is not something any government can consider no matter what is inscribed on them. The Congress government under PM Rao faced the riots that came with the revelations of the temple demolition at Ayodha and that led to tragic consequences.

The Law is "harsher" than Justice Verma's recommendations. Justice Verma's report doesn't recommend the death penalty - the new law requires it if the victim dies. They may not have implemented all of Justice Verma's recommendations but to call it "diluted" is plainly false.

Pornography and rape are as closely related as road-rage and indigestion. Most of the perpetrators of brutal rapes in these recent cases be it of the 23 year old girl raped on a moving bus or the 5 year old child raped in a room; were committed by men from poor villages with poor education doing menial jobs. These are not the kinds of people who have ready access to computers, internet and the wherewithal to search and seek out online pornography in India.

This is a good and not so good development. Not so good as we continue to be obsessed with marriage - at least parents do. Good because young men and women are at least beginning to understand that they need to have some interests in common, other than caste and religion.

What is worrying is that men and women cannot find spouses for themselves as they don't have the confidence in their own judgement. Coddled since birth and dominated by parents they never mature enough emotionally to develop and sustain a relationship with the opposite sex - one that could result in a permanent relationship. This is a shame. But, if marriages do have to be arranged, then these new sites are a welcome addition.

I live for the day that we Indians can get off the marriage bandwagon and parents stop craving for grandchildren and putting pressure on their children to have them.

India needs to regulate porn on cell phones and  block easy access at the server level. The smart ones will go around it, but they will hopefully be smart enough to control themselves. India being a democracy is not relevant in international relations. We have to do what works for us. There are still censors for Bollywood, why should the porn industry be immune?
